label: Letter from John F. Grimke to John Paul Grimke, February 1, 1778
description: A four-page letter written by John F. Grimke to his father, John Paul Grimke, regardng his arrival at Camp Purisburgh. Grimke describes the poor condition of the roads, the state of the militias in the Carolinas, and recruitment within "Continental Battalions." Grimke notes that unless more severe laws are passed regulating regional militias, it is probable that Americans would be forced to "submit to [their enemy's] Government."

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
Camp at Purisburgh to J.
P. G. Feb 1st 1779

Dear Sir.

I have the Pleasure of informing you
that I arrived in Camp a few days ago after four
and an half days difficult riding; never surely were
roads in so bad a Condition, many parts of them so
totally impossible that have [illegible] were obliged to
quit the direct rout and furnish their journey thro' the
woods. I found the Army in a State quite un-
prepared to march, owning to the [fairness?] of Men
who had as yet arrived in Camp; neither was
there a possibility of [us?] being Reinforced during
the Continuance of the bad roads. but I presume
it will be more agreeable to you to hear of
our present situation, which has lately grown
better, by an increase of about 1500 Men
under Gen: [General] Ash and Colo. [Colonel] [Strickland?]: but even with
this addition it does not appear feasible to
cross the River. Colo. [Colonel] Elbert is Detached to the
Westward with 400 Men then to Join Col.Hammond
and Gen: [General] Williamson and collect the Scattered
Friends of America still Remaining in Georgia
His Force it is supposed will consist of 1500,
or 1800 Men when collected, but to prevent such
an Union in the back Country the Enemy have
already detached a Considerable number and We are

[End page 1]

in [hasty?] Expectation of Receiving Express, some
intelligence of Importance. It is a great Chagrin
to us Carolinians whose first Pride and continual
boast it was, that we have always distinguished
Ourselves by a ready Compliance with Orders that
we should find the militia so slow, nay is averse
to serve during the Campaign, and that is some cases
they have shewn how little is to be Expected from
them. Tho' I do not charge my Countrymen with
want of Spirit; but think that they are deficient
in that Virtuous Principle which should at
this great Critical Juncture animate them to
turn out and Remain in the field until We
have Expelled the Enemy from our Vicinity.-
We are just informed that the Militia under
General Bull, have resolved that if Port Royal
is attacked that they will Strike the Cannon in
the fort and Relinquish the Island: Genl. [General] Moultrie
has this day set off for Beaufort; I hope his Endeavours
may meet with Sucess [success]. but I apprehend
that little it to be Expected from the present temper
of the People, unless for [Severe?] Laws
are without delay passed by the Legislature
for the [factoral?] Regulation of the Militia
the other States of America have been compelled
to draught their Militia to Serve in

[End page 2]

the Continental Battalions and by permitting
those Gentlemen who were draughted [drafted?] to purchase
Substitutes, a good and well Organized
Corps was immediately formed from the
lower class of People, who are more willing
in general to Obey Orders and are more capable
to endure the fatigues of a Campaign. the
Northern States after having Experimented
many different modes, [are?] necessitated at
length to pursue this letter measure in
order to Obtain [Pursuits?] and fill next their
Quarter in the Continental Battalions, If
the present disfigured Aspect of Affairs does
not Expect some Positive and Resolute Determination
from the House of Assembly,
[illegible] every little [else?] that We have to do,
than to make the best terms possible with
the Enemy and submit to their Government. but
I have a great deal to hope from the Good Verse
and great Spirit of my Countrymen, which have 
upon many occasions been very Cons[illegible]
and which is as much, if not more, required
at Present, than at any other Crisis of our
Affairs, which the Chance of War have occasioned.

[End page 3]

I hope as the Subject of this Letter is so
delicate, in [history?] and important that
you will not send it, or any part to the
Printers, since we leave from good info[rmation?]
that the Enemy have Persons who transmit
them such of the Prints as may be necessary
and intelligent to them. I am Dr [Dear] Sir with
Due Respect your Obs. Sert [Obedient Servant] and
Affece. Serv. [Affectionate Servant]
John F. Grimke

PS: Express arrived 300 of the Enemy landed
at Hilton Head and Count Several [illegible]

[Illegible] A Skirmish lately with the Enemy near
Bayan Creek in the back County of Georgia
Col. [Colonel] B[arson?] was wounded and 4 of his Men
were killed. Our People maintained the
Ground and the Enemy fled upon the above
loss.-

Comps [Compliments?] and Affection to My Mother and Sisters.

[End page 4]
